columns.text:
In this exercise, our task is to examine how bond prices fluctuate with a sudden change in interest rates.

Let's get started!

Let's start by explaining what the bond price is and how it's calculated. Bond price is the present discounted value of future cash returns generated by a bond. In other words, it can be described as the sum of the present values of all future coupon payments plus the present value of the face value at maturity: $$\text{Bond Price} = \text{Future Coupon Payments} + \text{Par value at maturity}

Recall that we can calculate the present value of the future coupon payments as follows:

$$\text{Future Coupon Payments} = C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) \tag{1}$$

Where:

C - Coupon payment

t - The number of compounding periods

YTM - Yield to maturity

We can calculate the face value of the bond at maturity by performing the following calculation:

$$\text{Par Value At Maturity} = \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \tag{2}$$

Where:

FV - Face value

YTM - Yield to maturity
 
t - Number of compounding periods

We can now input Eq. (1) and Eq. (2) in the original equation to calculate the bond price : $$\text{Bond Price} = C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t}$$ Using this equation, we can calculate the price of bonds Sam and Dave for the given parameters.

The exercise test states that the current bond price for both bonds is equal to their face value. Both bonds, Sam and Dave, have a face value of $1,000. Therefore, they both have a starting price of $1,000: $$\text{Bond Price}_\text{ Sam} = \$1,000$$ $$\text{Bond Price}_\text{ Dave} = \$1,000$$

Let's first calculate the bond prices for bond Sam when the interest rate both increase and decrease by 2%. We are given the following information on bond Sam: 1. The face value is assumed at $1,000 2. The annual coupon rate is 6.5%. The semiannual coupon rate is calculated by dividing the annual rate by 2 - the semiannual coupon rate is thus 3.25% 3. Considering that the time to maturity is three years, the number of compounding periods will be 6. This is because the bond pays out the coupons semiannually. 4. The annual yield to maturity is 6.5%.

If the annual yield to maturity is suddenly increased by 2%, then the semiannual yield to maturity will be 4.25% (8.5% divided by 2).

By plugging the given values (along with the increased yield to maturity) into the formula, we get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond Price}_\text{ Sam} &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] 
&= (\$1,000 \times0.0325) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.0425)^{6}}}{0.0425}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.0425)^{6}} \\[15pt] 
&= \$168.99154 + \$779.01105 \\[15pt] 
&= \$948.00259
\end{aligned}$$

If the annual yield to maturity is suddenly decreased by 2%, then the semiannual yield to maturity will be 2.25% (4.5% divided by 2). By plugging the given values (along with the decreased yield to maturity) into the formula, we get: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_\text{ Sam} &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] &= (\$1,000 \times0.0325) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.0225)^{6}}}{0.0225}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.0225)^{6}} \\[15pt] &= \$180.52049 + \$875.02427 \\[15pt] &= \$1055.54476 \end{aligned}$$ What happens with the bond price when the interest rate increases? What if the interest rate decreases?

The interest rate increases by 2%, and the price of the bond Sam changes by: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Price change} &= \dfrac{\text{New price} - \text{Starting price}}{\text{Starting price}} \\[15pt] &= \dfrac{\$948.00259 - \$1,000}{\$1,000} \\[15pt] &= \dfrac{-\$51.99741}{\$1,000} \\[15pt] &= -0.05199741 \\[15pt] &= -5.199741\% \end{aligned}$$ When the interest rate is raised by 2%, the bond price will decrease by 5.199741%.

The interest rate decreases by 2% and the price of the bond Sam changes by: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Price change} &= \dfrac{\text{New price} - \text{Starting price}}{\text{Starting price}} \\[15pt] &= \dfrac{\$1055.54476 - \$1,000}{\$1,000} \\[15pt] &= \dfrac{\$55.54476}{\$1,000} \\[15pt] &= 0.05554476 \\[15pt] &= 5.554476\% \end{aligned}$$ When the interest rate is decreased by 2%, the bond price will increase by 5.554476%.

Now let's analyze how the bond price changes for bond Dave when the interest rate increases or decreases by 2%. We are given the following information on bond Sam: 1. The face value is assumed at $1,000. 2. The annual coupon rate is 6.5%. The semiannual coupon rate is calculated by dividing the annual rate by 2 - the semiannual coupon rate is thus 3.25%. 3. Considering that the time to maturity is 20 years, the number of compounding periods will be 40. This is because the bond pays out the coupons semiannually. 4. The annual yield to maturity is 6.5%.

If the annual yield to maturity suddenly increases by 2%, the semiannual yield to maturity will be 4.25% (8.5% divided by 2).

By plugging the given values (along with the increased yield to maturity) into the formula, we get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond Price}_\text{ Dave} &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] 
&= (\$1,000 \times0.0325) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.0425)^{40}}}{0.0425}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.0425)^{40}} \\[15pt] 
&= \$620.01142 + \$189.21582  \\[15pt] 
&= \$809.22724
\end{aligned}$$

If the annual yield to maturity is suddenly decreased by 2%, then the semiannual yield to maturity will be 2.25% (4.5% divided by 2).

By plugging the given values (along with the decreased yield to maturity) into the formula, we get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond Price}_\text{ Dave} &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] 
&= (\$1,000 \times0.0325) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.0225)^{40}}}{0.0225}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.0225)^{40}} \\[15pt] 
&= \$851.28947 + \$410.64575 \\[15pt] 
&= \$1,261.93522
\end{aligned}$$

The interest rate increases by 2%, and the price of the bond Dave changes by: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Price change} &= \dfrac{\text{New price} - \text{Starting price}}{\text{Starting price}} \\[15pt] &= \dfrac{\$809.22724 - \$1,000}{\$1,000} \\[15pt] &= \dfrac{-\$190.77276}{\$1,000} \\[15pt] &= -0.19077276 \\[15pt] &= -19.077276\% \end{aligned}$$ When the interest rate is raised by 2%, the bond price will decrease by 19.077276%.

The interest rate decreases by 2%, and the price of the bond Sam changes by: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Price change} &= \dfrac{\text{New price} - \text{Starting price}}{\text{Starting price}} \\[15pt] &= \dfrac{\$1055.54476 - \$1,000}{\$1,000} \\[15pt] &= \dfrac{\$55.54476}{\$1,000} \\[15pt] &= 0.05554476 \\[15pt] &= 5.554476\% \end{aligned}$$ When the interest rate decreases by 2%, the bond price will increase by 5.554476%. Why does bond Dave have a higher bond price percentage change compared to bond Sam?

Finally, we'll draw a graph of how the price changes for different values of yield to maturity.

We'll start by recollecting all the resulting bond prices and putting them into the table below:

| Yield to maturity| Price of bond Sam| Price of bond Dave| 
|--|--|--| 
| 4.5% | \$948.00259 | \$809.22724| 
| 6.5% | $1,000 | \$1,000 | 
| 8.5% | \$1055.54476 | \$1,261.93522 | 

The results show that the bond Dave, which has a lengthier maturity period than bond Sam, is subject to higher price fluctuations as interest rates change.

Now let's draw the graph. 

Let the horizontal axis represent different yields to maturity, and the vertical axis represents bond prices. 

Here is how the graph should look: 

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/2b054c4e-eb9b-4d6b-8fb4-7979f3601a26-1653898609771763.png)

Let's recap what we have learned in this exercise!

First, we recalled how the bond price is calculated.

Then we calculated the bond prices for various values of yield to maturity. Our research has shown that bonds with longer maturity periods have higher interest rate risk and are subject to higher price fluctuations.

Finally, in the last step, we illustrated this rule by drawing a graph.
